Award.AwardTitle: QMHP: Multichannel interscale mixing: towards highly-parallel subwavelength imaging and focusing of light

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
QMHP: Multichannel interscale mixing: towards highly-parallel subwavelength imaging and focusing of light

Abstract
The objective of research is to develop a novel imaging paradigm that eliminates the need for bulky optical components such as lenses or mirrors and provides dramatic improvement of resolution. The approach relies on carefully designed diffractive elements that enable coupling between the waves carrying the information about different lengthscales of the object, and on advanced computational algorithms that recover the image based on the set of measured diffraction patterns.
Intellectual merit:
Proposed research focuses on the development of fundamentally new approach to imaging that utilizes diffractive, rather than reflective or refractive optics. The research has full potential to combine the benefits of deep subwavelenght resolution, offered by scanning near-field optical microscopy with benefits of large-area imaging offered by structured illumination microscopy. Diffraction-assisted imaging is uniquely positioned to utilize the four-fold reduction in wavelength in typical semiconductors to reduce the pixel size in mid-IR and long-wave IR detectors by an order of magnitude, opening the road to build highly-compact optics in these important frequency ranges.
Broader Impacts
Proposed research presents an opportunity to use recent progress in computation, materials science, and fabrication to revolutionize the full spectrum of imaging systems, from table-top microscopes to portable cameras, affecting life of ordinary people and researchers alike. The developed paradigm may become the ?workhorse? for optical characterization of novel nanostructures and for in-situ real-time imaging of small biological systems. Proposed mentoring, teaching, and outreach programs address the needs of high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students, and take advantage of the established productive theory-experiment collaborations

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science of light penetrates almost every aspect of our life. We assess our surroundings with vision, we detect pollutants or analyze the chemical composition of the matter with spectroscopy, we study the secrets of space with telescopes, and we use radars to enhance flight awareness and safety. For years (if not centuries), imaging and spectroscopy relied on lenses and mirrors to guide light from its source to our detectors. As the quality of lenses, prisms, and other refractive optical elements improved so did our ability to use optical devices and the benefits we get when using these devices. In particular, better optics resulted in better resolution of optical systems.

 

Unfortunately, resolution of refractive optics is fundamentally limited to approximately half of free-space wavelength by the fundamental law known as diffraction limit. Conventional (refractive) imaging devices cannot resolve two elements that are closer than half a wavelength to each other. Alternatively, pixels of in multi-pixel detectors (such as CCDs) cannot be placed closer than half a wavelength to each other.

 

Diffractive optics that relies on elements with the wavelength scale-structure, can overcome the limitations of conventional refractive optics. Unfortunately, the image generated by diffractive optics is really a “picture”. Rather, diffractive elements encode the information about the source of radiation into a complex pattern. This program was aimed at understanding the perspectives of diffractive optics paradigm “beyond diffraction limit”.

 

The program pursued two major thrusts. The first of these thrusts aimed at improving resolution of microscopy while the second thrust aimed at enabling ultra-compact imaging arrays with sub-wavelength pixels. As result of the program, new approach to microscopy, interscale mixing microscopy (IMM), has been developed. In IMM, the object or set of objects are positioned in the close (sub-wavelength) proximity to a pre-designed diffraction element. The objects are then illuminated by light and the diffracted light is collected by the detector. Numerical optimization is then used to deduce the structure of the object based on (i) patterns generated by the object on the diffraction element and on (ii) the optical properties of bare diffractive element. Performance of IMM was tested in computer-based experiments. It was shown that IMM has potential to achieve the resolution of the order of 1/20-th of free-space wavelength of light (Fig.1).

 

In the second thrust of the program, we have demonstrated that diffractive optics can be used in combination with high-refractive-index materials to dramatically enhance the pixel density in optical detectors. In particular, implementation of diffractive optics in widely-used semiconductor (refractive index of the order of 3) detectors may yield 10-fold enhancement of pixel density. This development may open the doors for highly compact thermal cameras, as well as for compact radars and THz scanners. As additional benefit, diffractive optics effectively spreads the information about each incident beam of light over multiple regions of detector. The resultant pattern contains the information about distribution of light throughout the space in front of the camera, opening the possibility to re-focus and re-explore the images after the picture has been taken (Fig.2).

 

To achieve the above outcomes, new tools for analysis of interaction of light with complex microscale materials have been developed.

 

The project provided ample opportunities for training both undergraduate and graduate students, eventually resulting in one B.S. thesis, two M.S. theses, and two Ph.D. theses. All students involved in this research are currently pursuing their careers in STEM disciplines. &nb...
